{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3602213,"name":"Arjun Ohri","username":"arjunorsmth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arjunorsmth/{size}/263909_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T11:41:29.132Z","cooked":"

Hi CD!

Going to preface this with a little explanation of why I‚Äôm writing this post, questions/TLDR at the bottom for those who don‚Äôt want to read all of this.

5667's 2025 Season Recap

This year, our team struggled a LOT.

We barely managed to field a functioning drivebase before the end of our first event, and were confined to being defense only for our second(and final) event of the season. This was a huge feels-bad season, because last year we actually ended up seeding first at our second regional and went to worlds, getting picked as a backup bot for the #2 alliance.

This was mostly due to the perennial and prevalent problem of senior turnover. Our CRESCENDO season was so successful because three of our seniors that year poured more hours than what was probably healthy for them into it, with pretty much the entire rest of our team sitting on the sidelines. After losing them to the horrible fate of graduation, I was pretty much the only person to continue work during the offseason, learning how to design from scratch and gaining enough skill to be our design lead and am pretty darn proud of how far I‚Äôve gotten with it. I‚Äôll probably make a separate topic about the organizational issues we‚Äôve faced, but I have a feeling a little digging will bring up some threads that describe very similar situations. However, our biggest issue by far this year was that our fabrication team was completely inexperienced(genuinely rookie-tier) and nobody(including me) correctly estimated how much time we‚Äôd need to spend on the build, leading to an EXTREMELY rushed robot and not delivering on any of the design capabilities this year.

With all that being said, what have teams done to improve the speed and quality of their builds? I‚Äôm looking to get a bunch of training in this offseason to help make up the experience gap, but I‚Äôm sure there are teams on CD that have been in similar positions that they found out how to dig themselves out of. Our machine shop could use some new equipment, our students could do with a little more learning, and I‚Äôve seen time and time again that the best way to get better at building robots is to build more robots.

Looking for tips, advice, or long writeups if I‚Äôm very lucky and people are very kind . How have teams been able to improve their build quality outside of design through machining practices and training programs? Is there any must-have equipment that I might not know about? How do teams create and enforce build schedules(examples would also help!)? I have a feeling that this problem is going to require the creation of a lot of base processes and a little bit of the nitty gritty stuff(new machines and equipment), so any implementations of those would be great to hear too!

TLDR:

Bad season for my team. How can we improve our build speed and quality? How does YOUR team approach planning build season and training fabrication students? What operations should a regional-competitive team be able to do in house, and to what level of precision? Any tips or tricks that might help a rising team captain to dig their team out of this hole?

As always, I appreciate anyone who takes the time to read this, and double thanks to anyone who responds

Tools/Machines

We have :

  • A battery of 3D printers
  • 2 cordless drills and a whole bunch of drill bits(although both are very old and many bits are blunted)
  • Pretty much any wiring equipment that a team would commonly have
  • Common hand tools(hammers, screwdrivers, hex drivers, etc.)
  • A very old CNC router(can find out what model the next time I‚Äôm in the shop)
  • A chop saw
  • A drill press
  • A bench grinder
  • A laser cutter

I want:

  • New drills and bits
  • A battery powered rivet gun
  • A hydraulic crimper for our battery wires
  • An arbor press
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T11:41:29.132Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":22,"reads":538,"readers_count":537,"score":252.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500359,"topic_slug":"improving-build-speed-and-quality","display_username":"Arjun Ohri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66645,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5667 Captain/Driver/Design/Sponsorships Lead"},"post_url":"/t/improving-build-speed-and-quality/500359/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602216,"name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","username":"Billfred","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T11:57:38.774Z","cooked":"

A lot of this is going to require a bit more understanding on where you came up short this year. There aren‚Äôt pictures on TBA, and all I can glean from the videos is the original concept was ‚Äúsome kind of swerve elevator‚Äù.

How often were you meeting, both in the fall and during the season?

What decision making led you to the concept you chose?

Did anything change in your approach to swerve this year? (I can see you were swerving in 2024.)

What COTS components, if any, were you using in the build?

You mentioned you learned how to design over summer and became design lead. Were others in the process with you, either also designing or in reviewing it?

When did you start fabrication?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T11:57:38.774Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":472,"readers_count":471,"score":114.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500359,"topic_slug":"improving-build-speed-and-quality","display_username":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.thebluealliance.com/team/5667/2025","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"The Digital Eagles - Team 5667 (2025) - The Blue Alliance","clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":3095,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"is recovering from IRI"},"post_url":"/t/improving-build-speed-and-quality/500359/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602217,"name":"Sam","username":"clydefrog88","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/clydefrog88/{size}/150683_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T11:57:55.590Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôm going to give you a one-liner because I truly think this is good advice for all but ~100 teams in the world.

Intentionally build less robot than you‚Äôre capable of.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T11:57:55.590Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":444,"readers_count":443,"score":288.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500359,"topic_slug":"improving-build-speed-and-quality","display_username":"Sam","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":12}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7309,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/improving-build-speed-and-quality/500359/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":12,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602220,"name":"Hadi Al Sati","username":"Hadia13","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hadia13/{size}/265915_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T11:59:43.093Z","cooked":"

My team also dosent have the best time management and that cost us quite a lot this season. Elbows are the notes we took away after competition season ended, with an explicit plan to implement weekly checklists, appoint a task manger and to create a running list of issues that we faced during testing that MUST get fixed before competition. Below are our entire notes for the meeting if you would like to check it out.

  • TVR ‚Üí recap and stuff we did that‚Äôs good/ bad

    • Robot not being fully functional
    • Robot was inconsistent
    • Lack of driver practice/stress testing
    • Unique robot
    • Learning curve
    • People scouting too many matches on Castle, tech and personal stress issues
    • Good team spirit
    • Great organized pit, looked good
    • Crossing Ts and dotting I‚Äôs, pay attention to details, focus on the little things
    • TVR was a wakeup call
    • 191 checking in
    • 4122 and Emu Robotics also checked in

  • NYC

    • Best record since 2014
    • First judged award since 2019
    • Better scouting, do your scouting
    • Second round picks are very important
    • Have someone in charge of comp scouting (NOT HADI)
    • DId a good job with engineering judging
    • Have an ENB
      • Document iterations etc.
      • Implement with OA
    • Tryouts for impact

  • Actual stuff we can implement

    • Weekly checklist - have someone in charge of organizing build season
    • Running list of issues and address those issues
    • Solve problems here, not at comp, makes it much harder
    • Stricter deadlines
    • Organized delegation system
    • No underneath electrical
    • Do not rush things, be patient, electrical department and programming department
    • Take photos of top teams, ask about team mechanisms, programming, etc.
    • Stick and implement plan
    • Listen more/ listen to mentors more
      • Right about underneath electrical
      • Right about swerve tread wheels
      • Be more open minded. Not just to mentors but students as well
        • At comp as well, towards other teams, rambots are an example of that
    • Have a clear cut identity - something we are special for
    • Assign roles and responsibilities
      • What do the leads do: have clear cut ideas and responsibilities
    • Weight constraints for individual mechanisms
    • Communicate better
    • Prototype faster
    • Weekly recap posted in teams
      • Figure out who does it - team leads should do that for their department or someone can do it for everyone
    • Have a CAD library
      • Use/Adjust old designs
      • Look at other teams old robots
        • 254 has open CAD library that is accessible to all
        • OA threads, 694, etc.
      • Only need to change the geometry
    • Cheer for impact, dean‚Äôs list, AND for the robot
    • Cheer and celebrate other teams milestones
    • Make LED signs and other tools for team spirit
    • Do not loiter at the pit
      • Only have 7 people at the maximum at the pit
    • Lean into team image
    • Results and findings have a reciprocal relationship, awards lead to funding, funding leads to results
    • Rookies could make team spirit equipment
    • Rookies learn by doing, not watching
    • Task manager, assigns work and roles, find person to do that
    • Offseason rookie robot
      • Mini robot?
    • Homecoming coming up, Apr 26, 2025
      • Need 5 people to be there
      • Get branch from 1601 or make a new reef
    • Make sure we are uploading stories and posts throughout competition
","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T11:59:43.093Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":427,"readers_count":426,"score":170.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500359,"topic_slug":"improving-build-speed-and-quality","display_username":"Hadi Al Sati","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62772,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"334 drive coach and strategy lead"},"post_url":"/t/improving-build-speed-and-quality/500359/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602228,"name":"Ethan Grieshop","username":"CakeDeer6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cakedeer6/{size}/264680_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T12:12:40.649Z","cooked":"

I think you guys may have just set your sights a little too high this season. While ground intakes are super cool, putting one on at the cost of 3-4 weeks of your build season isn‚Äôt a great trade off. Adding complexity like that makes everything take longer, from prototyping, to design, to build, to programming, and especially driver training.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T12:12:40.649Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":304,"readers_count":303,"score":90.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500359,"topic_slug":"improving-build-speed-and-quality","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/improving-build-speed-and-quality/500359/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602235,"name":"Arjun Ohri","username":"arjunorsmth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arjunorsmth/{size}/263909_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T12:23:40.507Z","cooked":"

We officially meet on Mondays and Wednesdays for 2 hours, and Saturdays for 3 hours, but most work actually happens in unofficial meetings after our school day ends.

There is posted CAD and a writeup I made here about this year‚Äôs robot. Several things have changed since then but the overall concept is the same.

Our design decisions mostly happened on an open chat between current design members and alumni. I solo designed our robot this year, and I could definitely feel my inexperience in some places. We overscoped for sure and that‚Äôs on me, but we have a habit of designing more robot than we should and our alumni didn‚Äôt really stop meüòÖ. The reason I focus on build quality and speed rather than this is because I know enough now to limit scope for next year, and we still weren‚Äôt able to deliver on what a team reasonably should be able to in the span of a season fabrication-wise.

Our swerve didn‚Äôt majorly change this year. We used Tuner X to generate swerve, our main issues came in wiring because nobody really knew how to wire well until about week 3 of the season(this sounds much worse than I thought it would when writing this)

Most everything in the build was COTS if it could be, nothing that I designed wasn‚Äôt easily manufacturable with our resources. We experienced more issues with assembly and tolerances on parts that needed to be cut to length.

As I mentioned above, I solo designed this year. I had two alumni to help me out with design decisions and I posted my design to DDS for a design review which helped quite a bit. Nobody else on our team currently knows how to design.

We started immediately on the drivebase, which was finished by the end of week 1. From there, we waited for the design to be done, which took another week and a half(not sure if this is something we need to speed up or do concurrently). Our real issue came after when I made a spreadsheet of all the manufacturing tasks we needed done after design was finished, and got sick. I couldn‚Äôt go to meetings for a week and was expecting some progress but things hadn‚Äôt started at all. I also severely underestimated the time it would take to assemble the robot, relying on our official meetings for another week until I realized how behind we were. Not many people on our team were very involved, maybe 1 or 2 along with me intermittently, but we ended up making enough progress to have our elevator built and mounted by end of February(when I had expected the robot to be done and ready for software). I started coming in every day and assembling for as long as I could, but even with that I couldn‚Äôt finish our subsystems and mount all of them before our first competition.

Hope this answers your questions.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T12:23:40.507Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":312,"readers_count":311,"score":82.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500359,"topic_slug":"improving-build-speed-and-quality","display_username":"Arjun Ohri","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/looking-for-a-design-review/482985","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Looking for a design review","clicks":14}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":3095,"username":"Billfred","name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66645,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5667 Captain/Driver/Design/Sponsorships Lead"},"post_url":"/t/improving-build-speed-and-quality/500359/6","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602287,"name":"Casey - 3602 Eng. Mentor","username":"EskyYooper","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eskyyooper/{size}/224416_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T13:41:45.417Z","cooked":"

This is really a great one liner and encapsulates so much.

Sam:

I‚Äôm going to give you a one-liner because I truly think this is good advice for all but ~100 teams in the world.

Intentionally build less robot than you‚Äôre capable of.

We started a 2nd team this year for new members and our FTC 8th graders. They built a RI3D bot with no vision and simple sensors. They were an alliance captain at one event, Event finalist Captain at the next, and finished comfortably middle at the Michigan States. They focused on doing simple things well and reliably.

In comparison our ‚Äúlead‚Äù robot team spent a ton of time on complex systems that never worked (4 camera vision) as well as not doing the simple things competently. It wasn‚Äôt a bad robot but the team bit off way more than they could chew and accrued a huge technical debt that they didn‚Äôt have the time to deal with.

Our team goal is to be a solid alliance partner. Michigan is too tough of a neighborhood to try and beat the likes of Rush or Stryke Force, but we can really make an awesome partner.

Our thoughts for next year is deal with technical debt in the off season and don‚Äôt make major changes during the on-season.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T13:42:09.353Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":227,"readers_count":226,"score":110.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500359,"topic_slug":"improving-build-speed-and-quality","display_username":"Casey - 3602 Eng. Mentor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66012,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/improving-build-speed-and-quality/500359/7","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602314,"name":"Christopher149","username":"Christopher149","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/838e76/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T14:14:05.676Z","cooked":"
arjunorsmth:

We barely managed to field a functioning drivebase before the end of our first event

Do you have any more details on this? Was it mechanical, programming, something else? The other posts don‚Äôt emphasize this, but test early and often (though not too often). We we‚Äôre testing our swerve around February 7-8, which was good because there were code changes by REV and we had an encoder angle off by 180 degrees. Unfortunately we didn‚Äôt get to testing pathplanner changes until much closer to the competition, but that still went okay.

On the flip side, we had an FTC season where I remember doing too many practice events that we didn‚Äôt really have time to properly build anything and kept taking some things off to be better for the practice, so you do need enough time to build and program and test things.

On the manufacturing side, we are aggressively COTS because our tooling is basically just band saw, drill press, jigsaw, hand drill, and we meet in the home ec room. This also means that there isn‚Äôt much barrier to making things as long as they aren‚Äôt custom and just involve cutting things.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T14:16:14.260Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":192,"readers_count":191,"score":58.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500359,"topic_slug":"improving-build-speed-and-quality","display_username":"Christopher149","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14984,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor"},"post_url":"/t/improving-build-speed-and-quality/500359/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602318,"name":"Arjun Ohri","username":"arjunorsmth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/arjunorsmth/{size}/263909_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T14:18:36.945Z","cooked":"

This was mostly due to wiring issues and tunnel vision. We had a ton of issues with CAN wiring that we only fully fixed two days before our competition, and then proceeded to focus getting our elevator mechanically finished rather than testing our drivebase(bad decision in hindsight). Ended up having more issues with wiring at competition, finally got sorted out on Saturday of our first competition.

Good, efficient cad definitely help speed up the build process. This was a big differentiator for us between last season and this season. I would very highly recommend checking out frcdesign.org

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T18:43:50.851Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":157,"readers_count":156,"score":46.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500359,"topic_slug":"improving-build-speed-and-quality","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"http://frcdesign.org","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"FRCDesign.org","clicks":8}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61769,"hidden":false,"trust_level":3,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Onshape enjoyer"},"post_url":"/t/improving-build-speed-and-quality/500359/10","reactions":[{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602880,"name":"","username":"AaronUp","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/aaronup/{size}/151708_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T19:11:19.542Z","cooked":"
EskyYooper:

Our team goal is to be a solid alliance partner.

I think this is what helped lay the foundation for us to up our success on the field. Instead of trying to do everything we tried to determine what top teams would do, and then be the best compliment for that.

If the goal is simply success on the field its better to start small and build from there. Analyzing this years game you could assume 6-8 of L4 coral would be covered by top teams in auto, leaving only 4-6 more cycles. Do you think any top team would not be able to handle that? We found in our scouting a lot of teams that would be much faster to play L2/3 but spend a lot of the match getting half as many L4 cycles.

It‚Äôs hard to look at the game and not want to do everything, but hopefully evaluating your resources and designing for those will help next season. We knew going into this season we had a pretty limited cad crew and green manufacturing team. We chose to use Eliot‚Äôs belt in tube elevator as inspiration, and off the shelf bearing blocks to get us started. This let us get our elevator together relatively quickly, and then fix/replace things as necessary.

We also use week 0 as our goal. That requires a robot to be mostly manufactured and assembled in about 4-5 weeks. This year we were a little behind that and rebuilt after week 0, but had planned for it ahead of time.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":13,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T19:12:19.053Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":147,"readers_count":146,"score":59.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500359,"topic_slug":"improving-build-speed-and-quality","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":3564,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1768 Drive Coach "},"post_url":"/t/improving-build-speed-and-quality/500359/11","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3603135,"name":"Ian Osborn","username":"Sands","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/22d042/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T22:19:52.092Z","cooked":"

That‚Äôs a really nice robot design!

A design that I‚Äôd only do if I had ~10 build kids and ~10 code kids who where all locked in and productive.

Tuning ground intakes is harder than it looks. Perhaps a chute load robot? That would have removed ~2 DOF of mechanisms and work.

Or start with a concept that can do Chute and well as ground, then add ground later?

I realize the season is over, but as proxy examples for next year.

We‚Äôre going to do some offseason work to ‚Äúpre-design‚Äù core mechanisms. This year we used a ~90% stock Thrifty Bot elevator, a riff off the WCP concept for the coral / Algae claw, an Open Alliance climber. Our ‚Äúnew‚Äù CAD work was pretty minimal. That saved our bacon this year.

The plan for next year is to (like said above) intentionally design for less than I think we‚Äôre capable of and make things amenable to a future upgrade between events or for champs. Agreed that this design takes quite a bit of student resources, maybe we can build complex the year before I graduate!
